title: Top Stock Movers Now: Vertex, DoorDash, Constellation Energy, and More
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • U.S. equities dropped at midday as the markets awaited any news on tariffs and tomorrow's Fed decision.
  • Higher costs and issues with Russia led Vertex Pharmaceuticals to miss profit and sales estimates.
  • Constellation Energy beat revenue forecasts and reiterated its full-year earnings guidance on strong artificial intelligence energy demand.


U.S. equities were lower at midday as the market watched for any possible deals involving Trump administration tariffs and awaited tomorrow's statement from the Federal Reserve policymakers following their two-day meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all fell.

Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) shares plunged after the biotech firm missed profit and sales estimates on higher costs and issues with sales in Russia.

Shares of DoorDash (DASH) slumped when the food-delivery service missed revenue estimates and made a pair of acquisitions, including a $3.9 billion purchase of British firm Deliveroo.

Coterra Energy (CTRA) shares slid when the oil and gas producer said it was cutting back on capital spending because of macroeconomic uncertainty and the falling price of oil. 

Constellation Energy (CEG) was the best-performing stock in the S&P 500 when the nuclear power provider easily exceeded revenue forecasts and held its full-year profit outlook steady on rising demand for energy from artificial intelligence (AI) applications.

Shares of Ford Motor (F) advanced as the carmaker said auto tariffs won't cause a significant increase in the price of new vehicles.

Leidos Holdings (LDOS) shares jumped after the defense and technology firm posted better-than-anticipated results as security and defense contracts grew.

Oil and gold futures gained. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note was basically unchanged. The U.S. dollar lost ground to the euro, pound, and yen. Prices for most major cryptocurrencies were mixed, with bitcoin ticking higher.
titles: Top Stock Movers Now: Vertex, DoorDash, Constellation Energy, and More
summary: U.S. equities declined midday as markets awaited tariff news and the Federal Reserve's decision. Vertex Pharmaceuticals missed profit and sales forecasts due to higher costs and issues in Russia, causing shares to drop. Constellation Energy outperformed in the S&P 500, beating revenue predictions and maintaining its earnings outlook, benefiting from increased AI energy demand. Other notable movements included DoorDash and Coterra Energy shares falling due to missed revenue estimates and reduced capital spending, respectively. Meanwhile, Ford and Leidos Holdings saw shares rise due to tariff im
constructiveness_reason: This story provides actionable insights for investors and contributes to their decision-making process. It informs about the performance of different stocks, which can be useful for investment decisions. However, it doesn't provide a broader context or highlight solutions to the issues faced by the companies mentioned.

title: Tectonic Surprise: Mantle Upwelling, Not Mega-Crunch, Built Earth’s “Roof of the World”
snippets: Tibetan uplift was mainly caused by post-collisional mantle dynamics, not ongoing India-Asia convergence. The study challenges long-held tectonic models. The India-Asia continental collision and the rise of the Tibetan Plateau have traditionally been explained by continuous convergence throughout the Cenozoic, based on two main assumptions: that the India-Asia collision is ongoing and that the Indian [...]
titles: Tectonic Surprise: Mantle Upwelling, Not Mega-Crunch, Built Earth’s “Roof of the World”
summary: A recent study has revealed that the elevation of the Tibetan Plateau, often referred to as the "Roof of the World," was primarily driven by mantle upwelling rather than the longstanding theory of the India-Asia tectonic plate convergence. This challenges the traditional understanding of the plateau's formation, which attributed its rise to the continuous collision of the Indian and Asian continental plates since the Cenozoic era. The findings suggest that post-collisional mantle dynamics played a key role in shaping the region's topography.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides a deeper understanding of geological processes and challenges traditional theories, which can be useful for readers interested in geology or earth sciences. However, it does not provide actionable insights or report on solutions or improvements.

title: 17 Years Later, Scientists May Have Finally Solved the Extreme Rainfall Mystery
snippets: New research shows that extreme rainfall increases follow expected temperature relations when rainfall types are separated, resolving a long-standing debate but reinforcing concerns about future flash flood risks under climate change. Extreme rainfall can lead to rapid and dangerous flooding known as flash floods. Understanding how such intense rainfall responds to rising temperatures has been [...]
titles: 17 Years Later, Scientists May Have Finally Solved the Extreme Rainfall Mystery
summary: After 17 years of study, scientists have discovered that extreme rainfall patterns align with expected temperature increases when different types of rainfall are considered separately. This finding resolves a long-standing debate and highlights the growing risk of flash floods due to climate change.
constructiveness_reason: The story informs about the relationship between extreme rainfall patterns and temperature increases, highlighting the risks of climate change. This can help readers understand the impacts of climate change and the need for mitigation efforts. However, it doesn't provide specific solutions or improvements.

constructiveness_reason: This story clearly highlights an innovation aimed at solving a problem - faster identification of natural disaster locations to aid rescue operations. It provides actionable insights and increases awareness about the use of seismic data in disaster management.

title: Satellites Tracked a Volcano’s Secret Collapse for 12 Years – Then It Sparked a Killer Wave
snippets: In 2018, the Anak Krakatau volcano in Indonesia collapsed catastrophically, generating a deadly tsunami. Now, researchers reveal that the volcano’s flank had been slowly slipping for years—an invisible danger detectable through satellite radar long before disaster struck. Silent Slippage Before Disaster In 2018, a massive eruption caused the southwest flank of Indonesia’s Anak Krakatau volcano [...]
titles: Satellites Tracked a Volcano’s Secret Collapse for 12 Years – Then It Sparked a Killer Wave
summary: In 2018, the Anak Krakatau volcano in Indonesia underwent a catastrophic collapse, leading to a deadly tsunami. Recent research has shown that satellite radar detected the volcano's southwest flank was slowly slipping for 12 years prior to the eruption. This gradual movement, not visible to the naked eye, was a critical precursor to the eventual disaster.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the potential for satellite radar to detect precursors to natural disasters. However, it doesn't offer a clear solution or innovation to prevent such disasters, nor does it provide actionable insights for the reader. It does increase awareness about the causes and impacts of natural disasters.

title: Upcycled grape pomace in chicken feed may improve their gut health
